stem: A teammate emails an Excel sheet labeled “all-staff passwords” saying, “Just in case I’m sick tomorrow.” The sheet is protected by one master password written in the email body.

choices.A: Download and store the sheet on a shared drive
choices.B: Suggest using a password manager the whole team can access securely
choices.C: Forward the sheet to HR for backup
choices.D: Change only your own entries to something simpler

stem: Your phone receives an SMS from the bank informing you of an unusual login and sent you a link to reset your password. The link asks for old password before choosing a new one.

choices.A: Follow the SMS link to reset before something bad happens
choices.C: Open the bank’s app directly and review recent logins
choices.D: Ignore the SMS, the bank will call if serious

stem: During game night, a friend offers to store everyone’s Wi-Fi passwords in a shared group chat so no one forgets next time, noting the chat is set to friends-only.

choices.B: Post the password, it’s just Wi-Fi so it's not really dangerous
choices.A: Suggest sharing the password verbally each session instead
choices.C: Change the network name to hide the password need
choices.D: Pin the password message for easy reference

stem: A study blog recommends an easy pattern method: pick a base word and add “2025” for every new account to remember fewer passwords.

choices.A: Copy the tip as memorable and quick
choices.D: Create unique long passwords even if harder to recall
choices.C: Use the pattern but change the year each month
choices.B: Save the base word in a notes app and lock it in case you forget

stem: Your company’s new rule demands 12-character passwords with letters and numbers, but the intranet system still accepts “Winter2022”. IT insists it’s fine because the length is right.

choices.A: Keep ‘Winter2022’ as long as policy is met
choices.B: Add symbols and avoid common words for stronger security
choices.D: Ignore until IT forces a change

stem: Working remotely, you receive a VPN prompt: “Your password expires in 5 hours; click here for the quick-reset portal.” The portal URL contains your company name plus extra digits.

choices.A: Log into HR app directly and check expiry there
choices.C: Copy the link into a document for later
choices.D: Skip, you can work offline until tomorrow

stem: Which of these passwords most reduces guessability while remaining memorable according to best practice?
Your sibling tapes the family router’s admin password behind the device so technicians won’t bother you during service visits. The password is long and random.

choices.A: Leave it as only technicians see it
choices.B: Store the password in a manager and remove the paper label
choices.C: Shorten it to something easier to type
choices.D: Add 2-3 digits to the label for confusion

stem: News breaks that an online retailer you use was breached last week. You reuse that password on three other sites.

choices.C: Change passwords on all sites that share the same one
choices.B: Wait for confirmation email before acting
choices.D: Enable ‘remember me’ so you know which sites break

stem: A project manager asks you to embed the admin password inside a PDF contract in case we lose the sticky note, and email it to a vendor.

choices.A: Do it—password lives inside a document
choices.B: Refuse and suggest a secure alternative
choices.C: Send half the password and text the rest
choices.D: Rename the PDF ‘meeting-notes’ so no one looks

stem: Which statement best explains why enabling two-step verification and using different passwords for every site offers stronger protection than either practice alone?

choices.A: The second step hides password length
choices.B: It prevents attacks that succeed when only one defense fails
choices.D: Both practices confuse hackers with fake data

stem: Your company now forces a password change every 60 days. Explain, briefly, practical methods you’ll use to keep strong, unique passwords without forgetting them.

rubric.point: Generate long passphrases or complex random strings

stem: You are setting up dozens of smart-home devices that all require admin passwords. Outline in a few sentences how you will create, store, and back up those passwords to stay secure over time.

rubric.point: Generate unique strong passwords for each device
Store them in an encrypted password manager with backup
Document recovery steps (master password, secure export) safely offline
